Award.AwardTitle: Electronic Delivery of Scaffolded Visualization Tutorials and Assessment in Chemistry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: While detailed molecular visualization is ubiquitous within chemistry and biochemistry teaching and learning, preliminary evidence collected by the Principal Investigator suggests that many instructors assume students have extracted the appropriate visual information but do not assess the accuracy of that assumption. To enhance student learning in the increasingly important on-line delivery of instruction, and particularly with respect to three-dimensional aspects of complicated molecular structures, this project is scaffolding content for visualization of chemical and biochemical systems. Concepts that are important for understanding activity or reactions are set within progressive learning methods that explicitly address the visual components of the representation and the cognitive components of the chemistry content. Using design principles from scholarship in Human-Computer Interaction, tools are being designed to enhance student interaction with these visualizations that focus on large molecular systems. How the students interact with web-based materials is being captured and distilled in order to better understand the nature of student self-directed exploration within the scaffolded learning environment. The project is also developing enhanced visualization methods in testing and is incorporating them with electronically delivered tests from the Examinations Institute of the American Chemical Society (ACS-EI). Findings are providing insight into the nature of measurement of student learning as a function of cognitive environments and which thereby is defining the relationship between visualization and measured student learning in molecular systems of varying visual and content complexity. Utilizing the established user base of the ACS-EI is allowing for extensive feedback of test items among a diverse population of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronic Delivery of Scaffolded Visualization Tutorials and Assessment in Chemistry

 

Outcome #1: Development of the Variable Representations Application (VRA)

-       An interactive interface was developed that allows students to navigate between different visual representations related to the science that they are learning, in order to answer a multiple-choice question. In the case of chemistry, the visual representations that can be navigated are different ways to depict molecules. Chemists often use somewhat different ways to depict molecules, and it is important for students who are learning chemistry to be able to learn when to use these different models for thinking about chemicals. The VRA interface has been through several iterations, and student participants in the testing of this instrument have indicated that the navigation between the various representations is intuitive and relatively easy to use. The VRA tracks, including time stamps, all the actions students take when they answer questions that use the interface. This provides considerably more information to the chemistry instructor, of chemistry education researcher, about the nature of critical thinking that students are using.

 

Outcome #2: Usability studies of the VRA using the System Usability Scale (SUS) survey.

-       In order to make sure that the VRA interface is introducing little or no measurement error when asking students questions about chemistry, usability studies were included at each stage of the development of the interface. Because the participants were already using a relatively large amount of time to carry out the tasks that are built into the current version of the VRA, it is important that the method used to assess usability be as short as possible. Arguably the most common assessment used in usability studies, given this constraint, is the System Usability Scale (SUS) survey. Our implementation of the SUS showed that, in general, student participants found the interface easy to use with scores that are generally considered acceptable for the SUS. At the same time, however, there are a few items in the survey that had somewhat average usability lower scores. Looking at these items, it appears that the wording used may result in students considering the challenge level of the chemistry content being presented within the VRA interface, rather than any challenges associated with the interface itself. This observation has led to ongoing research on the nature of the SUS instrument that may prove useful to better refine the instrument for use in educational environments, where students will experience different levels of complexity depending on their familiarity with the (science) content being presented. This content challenge is fine to have occur with on-line delivered assessment, but it is desirable to be able to separate the measures of science knowledge and interface usability as much as can be done.

 

Outcome #3: General Chemistry student reliance on Lewis structures as molecular representations.

-       Because the development of the VRA was routinely tested by general chemistry students at several universities, evidence about patterns of student usage of molecular representations was captured. This evidence suggests that students at this level of study have become quite familiar with Lewis structures as the representation of choice. This observation is not inherently surprising, because Lewis structures are quite likely the most common visual representations used in chemistry instruction. Chemical formulas are often used as well, but they contain much less structural information, so Lewis structures are quite important as models for thinking about chemistry at the molecular scale. Nonetheless, with the VRA it was possible to establish an over reliance on this representation model. Some chemistry question tested within the VRA application could not be answered using Lewis structures, because “unknown” atoms were introduced into those structures. For items with such unknowns, other available representations could easily provide the correct answer. Many students, however, spent much more time looking at the Lewis structures, than other representations that would be more fruitful in providing answers. Thus, there is evidence that instructional strategies for general chemistry may wish to consider explicitly introducing complementary representations other than Lewis structures, so that students develop a more robust palette of options for thinking about chemistry at the molecular scale.
